awd_titl_txt: EAGER SitS: Autonomous Soil Nutrient Sensing System
awd_abstract_narration:
Population growth, aggressive farming practices, and climate change have put significant stress on the food production system for sustainable growth. Agricultural runoff from over-fertilization and waste from large farms into natural water sources can cause algae outbreaks, reduce the dissolved oxygen in water, resulting in ecosystem disturbance and decline in fish populations. Precision agriculture with data-backed decision-making such as fine-grained spatiotemporal soil properties (moisture, temperature, pH, nutrients, organic matter, etc.) has potential to improve the efficiency of the farming practices by increasing crop growth and reducing agricultural runoff that contaminates surface and groundwater along with other negative environmental impacts. Current practice of soil property measurement relies heavily on taking samples for laboratory testing, which is costly and time consuming for implementation over large areas. This project will investigate a low-cost autonomous soil nutrient sensing system to support precision agriculture by integrating microelectromechanical system sensors, ground penetrating radar, as well as autonomous unmanned aerial vehicle-enabled wireless sensor network.

The project includes the development of a passive, low cost, pervasive, maintenance-free sensor that can be interrogated wirelessly and provide measurement of soil water content, temperature, pH, and nutrient concentration. The project focuses on detecting and evaluating nitrate and heavy metal ions concentration in the soil, which are indicators of agricultural runoffs and environmental contaminants. For this purpose, surface acoustic wave sensors that consist of surface acoustic wave delay lines and conductive polymer-based impedance sensors connected to a reflector will be considered as the main sensing modules. The sensors can be placed in the soil for in-situ measurement. The specific research objectives of this project are to: 1) identify specific polymers for nitrate and heavy metal ion detection, 2) design, fabricate and validate the surface acoustic wave sensors, 3) design and select proper antenna and ground penetrating radar for wireless measurement of the passive sensors, and 4) integrate the data analysis and communication system. The project team has a collective research expertise in biochemistry, radar and antenna design, microelectromechanical sensors, and communication networks in the field of electrical, computer, and mechanical engineering as well as life sciences. The success of this project can lead to significant improvement in the autonomous devices with novel antenna, communication system and nutrient sensor designs to measure signals in the soil at a reasonable cost and are scalable for deployment on a larger scale. The resulting integration of knowledge and expertise from multiple domains, and the generation of new methodologies and data, will provide the means to address pressing societal challenges in sustainable agriculture from a holistic design point of view. The project has potential to forge important new directions for several scholarly and professional disciplines that are oriented toward improving community resilience and train a cohort of undergraduate and graduate students from multiple disciplines to engage in scientific research and create usable scientific tools for stakeholders for a sustainable future.

por.por_cntn:
The project demonstrates a proof-of-concept implementation of an autonomous passive soil sensing system. The system integrates polymer sensor that can detect nitrate, surface acoustic wave sensor and a drone-enabled software defined radio wireless communication system for wireless data acquisition for soil nutrient measurement.

 1. PEDOT conducting polymer-based sensor for nitrate detection

The project fabricated and tested Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) as a conducting polymer sensor for nitrate detection. Vapor phase polymerization (VPP) method was used to fabricate the polymer thin film. Variations in specific parameters during the VPP process were tested and compared to develop new insights into PEDOT sensitivity towards nitrate ions. Our experiments show that the optimal fabrication parameters that produce a sensor with the highest sensitivity toward nitrate ions are a fabrication temperature of 42 oC, a pressure of -28.8 inHg, and a polymerization time of 50 mins. The conductivity of the polymer film with these parameters is 683 S/cm. The response to 1000 ppm nitrate solution is 41.79%. The sensors can detect nitrate ranging from 1 ppm to 1000 ppm. This sensor has excellent potential to detect nitrate ions in aqueous solutions in real-time.

2. Surface Acoustic Wave (SAW) sensor design and test

The propagation speed of surface acoustic waves is almost 100,000 times slower than that of electromagnetic waves. In SAW devices, interdigitated transducers (IDT) are used to convert the input electrical signal into an acoustic signal. The acoustic signal propagates along the substrate material. Then, the IDT on the output side converts the acoustic signal into an electrical signal to excite the polymer sensor. There are two reference reflectors set on the substrate material. When the acoustic signal encounters the reflector, a part of the signal will be reflected. There will be three reflected signals in the time domain response, the reflected signal from the polymer sensor, the reflected signals from the reference reflectors. Detection of the time delays among these peaks in the time domain allows us to measure the resistance change of the polymer sensor, which indicates the nitrate concentration.

3. Wireless data acquisition from sensors

The wireless data acquisition system uses software-defined radio (SDR) and surface acoustic wave (SAW) devices to obtain soil nutrient measurement. SDR uses software to realize different communication functions and can be programmed to function as a ground penetration radar. The system measures the magnitude and phase of the response at discrete frequencies and applies inverse Fourier transform to analyze the time domain responses which, in turn, allows for monitoring the changes in nutrient concentration in the soil.

4. Drone-enabled communication network

The project uses drones as a medium to carry the SDR to enable the communication network. To optimize the coverage, multiple drones are adopted. Energy-efficient and collision-avoidance multi-drone path planning algorithms are proposed to use the minimum number of drones to cover the maximum number of sensors in the field.  

5. System Integration

Each component was integrated into the final prototype system. The designed antennas were connected to the SAW sensor for receiving the electromagnetic waves from the GPR unit and send back the reflected signal from the SAW sensor toward the GPR unit. The following design requirements were considered for system integration: (1) directional radiation to avoid radiation toward ground and rather radiate toward GPR unit, (2) operation frequencey of 250 MHz, (3) compact size, (4) cost-effective fabrication. Two versions of cavity-backed printed spiral antennas were designed. First version was designed to operate while embedded inside the soil and a second version was designed to operate above the ground surface for initial tests and evaluations. The final antenna design follows a bow-tie antenna for best SNR for the test bed. To collect data from the passive sensors, drones are adopted to carry a GPR unit to fly within the vicinity of embedded sensors to activate and collect data. Path planning algorithms and optimization problems (energy-efficient min-max path planning problem, multi-depot vehicle routing problem, and collision avoidance in both 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional spaces) are formulated and examined to maximize the system operating time and ensure coverage of the desired surveying area.

The project brought together researchers from multiple disciplines to tackle a real-world challenge to build tools to help the understanding of agricultural activities on soil health and how to sustainably use the natural resources. It engaged more than ten undergraduate and graduate students from engineering and biological sciences as well as high school student to collaborate in designing research hypothesis and experiments to test the hypothesis. 

More detail of the project is available at https://sites.google.com/nyit.edu/sits/home
